text: all right we will kick off because i think we're bang on time thank you for joining me first up this morning um yeah big thanks
to to joining me i know there's lots of great talks on at the same time my name is donna edwards and i'm here
talking to you from australia if you couldn't already figure out that terrible accent that i have
and i'm here to talk to you about the leadership balancing act and how you can achieve success or at least feel like you're achieving
success without burning out about five years ago i was getting
really bad jaw pain i went to the dentist who sent me to a jaw specialist
and they said i was clenching at night and that it was most likely stress related and that i needed to sleep with
a plate on to help ease the pain the specialist said to me i can tell you're a type a personality
so this is probably never going to go away because you're always going to be stressed out and you just need to manage it using
this plate it was very sexy so i accepted my fate and i wore it
every night for the first few weeks until the pain eased up and then i would find that i could get away with wearing
it just a few times a week to keep the pain from coming back too much but i started to recognize when the
stress would kick in because my jaw would start to hurt so it was actually a really good way for me to start recognizing stress and listening
to my body about a year later i changed jobs i moved from a general manager hr role
into a state manager role for a smaller software development consultancy and i was just looking after 25 people
so it was a much much slower pace and within three weeks my jaw completely stopped hurting
and i've never had to wear the plate again and we're about five years down the track at this point
now the pace didn't stay slow because of course you know i made sure that the team grew and that we got
ridiculously busy but and i have come close to burnout full transparency i've
come close a couple of times in the last five years but what i've learned is to listen to my body's stress signals and learn tools
and strategies that i can implement to rewind the burnout and more importantly to try and prevent it from getting to that stage
i do want to acknowledge that it's an ongoing balancing act the practical tools and tips that i'm going to share with you today are things
that i check myself on and continue to practice every single month without fail but overall these things that i've
learned have helped me reach a place where i can feel successful feel like i'm adding value achieve the
things i want and take the time to enjoy my life and my work without feeling too stressed out
or too guilty that i'm not doing enough
so this talk is for people like me who want to achieve and feel successful but also feel overwhelmed with the
endless possibilities the amount of noise and requests that come from every direction the general busyness and the number of
priorities that we juggle and the many distractions and squirrels that come our way
i've spent the last 15 years refining these practical tips and gathering tools that work for me so i'm hoping that
sharing my lessons today will give you a few extra tools that you can use and share with your teams
there's a fair bit of content so always happy to chat later offline if you want more information on
a particular area so i split today into four key areas um and i guess talking through these will help
you realize whether you've come to the right place this morning so the first area is putting on your own
mask first so looking after yourself understanding yourself you know emotional intelligence
mindset burnout and prevention strategies the second area is working smarter not
harder so tips and tricks to be productive streamlining simplifying the third area
is leading like a pro so how to ensure that your team is achieving but dial down some of the noise that teams can really create for
you as a leader um and well we'll be part of that
and then the fourth is success and contentment you know we all work so hard and we have so many goals and things we
want to achieve so this one's really about making sure that you're taking the time to enjoy your work and your life and that you're
celebrating the wins so in order to add value to your company
your team the people in your personal life you need to be functioning and be okay
i love the aeroplane example of putting on your own mask first because if you don't look after yourself how can you help anyone else and how can
you be successful a really easy way to sanity check this is using a wellness wheel
i try and do this once a quarter so this is a check of our mind body heart soul things that are
important to us and what you do is you look at each of the areas and give them a rating out of ten
where do you want that to be you might not want it to be ten out of ten you might be happy with one area at seven
out of ten and there's lots of studies that call out relationships of sleep as towards the most important things
you can tailor these wheels though to suit you so for me i've replaced spirituality with career
and travel is another one that normally is on my wheel at the moment things are obviously a
little bit different i'd certainly love to be with you all in london i figure a lot of you are probably there
minus maybe minus the covered um but you know for me travel sometimes can get too much and can be overwhelming
and then sometimes it's not enough because i really miss it and i crave it so i put this on my wellness wheel and
it's something that i monitor you know every once a quarter at least so you can really tailor this to suit
you we do also need to acknowledge and accept that we live in a time where stress
worry anxiety is next level how many of you on this on this call today look at the news and the world and
feel some level of stress or anxiety at what's going on because i certainly do and the stats show that 77
of people experience stress that affects their physical health 73 of people experience stress that
affects their physical health and sorry mental health and 48 percent
of people have trouble sleeping because of stress so looking after our mental health is really important you can't help anyone
else if you're full of worry and anxiety and we have this constant stream of things that can cause worry and anxiety
and we rarely turn off from it i'm sure you've all heard about our bodies flight fight and freeze responses
and back in the day this would only happen occasionally when we were getting chased by a lion or whatever it was
now our brains are going in and out of this mode constantly and it's really exhausting for our minds and our bodies
when our emotions spike we can't see the full picture clearly anymore and we get this adrenaline boost and we
have laser focus which helps us unwrap out run the line or whatever it is we're trying to do
but this is actually the opposite to what we need in most of today's situations especially at work because when we're at
our calmest and most relaxed is when we can think the clearest and assess the full picture
i like the saying that the calmest person in the room wins because it really is true and it's so
hard to stay calm i want you to think for a moment how often you would describe yourself
as calm at work and then how often you describe yourself as calm at home
41 of workers believe that the biggest barriers to self or family care are feeling distracted and anxious
because they're not fully present so we can't care about everything and one of my favorite quotes from mark
manson is we only have so many cares to give or he doesn't quite use the word cares
but we need to be really clear about what's important to us and actually practice calming techniques to get our
bodies and minds used to being calm again the easiest way to do this is just deep breathing and
using reframing techniques which we'll talk about more a bit later
so the beginning of our journey of looking after ourselves and putting ourselves first is self-development and self-awareness
developing our emotional intelligence is the start of a much happier and successful life many companies now assess emotional
intelligence when people are applying for jobs and sometimes as part of performance appraisals
but in short emotional intelligence has an internal and an external component so internal is being aware of ourselves
our own abilities our emotions and our behaviors and external is being aware and understanding
other people's abilities emotions and behaviors when you develop these abilities by practicing and learning
you're able to regulate yourself better and better control external situations with conflict resolution and empathy
i've mentioned practicing a few times and that's because everything that i'm talking about today can all be learned they're all skills
that you can learn and develop through practicing one of the reasons i love working in the it industry and have done for over 20
years now is that the majority of people i get to work with are passionate about improving and learning in saying this i'm sure
we've all come across excellent technical people who get to a certain level and seem to think that the learning stops there
people who don't listen to feedback and don't work to improve their emotional intelligence and social awareness
this is what having a fixed mindset is being successful and happy in your life requires a growth mindset
and a growth mindset makes you more resilient because you can better cope with failure and setbacks because you view everything as an
opportunity to learn and to improve this image is taken from carol drake's book called mindset and definitely worth
a read and i will post a resources list at the end because there's going to be a lot of books and different
things that i talk about throughout this talk so the other important mindset is
abundance versus scarcity and i've no doubt you've all met someone who won't hire people who are better
than them because they feel threatened and they want to be the best and i'm sure you've all unfortunately met a manager who is more focused on
protecting their job than helping their team be successful they hold on to all their knowledge afraid to share it these people have a
scarcity mindset deep down they believe that for someone else to succeed they have to fail
for someone else to get a promotion must mean that their job is at risk it's a really sad way to live life
because there's a lot of fear and resentment on the other hand an abundance mindset is when people realize that we can all
be successful and that if we help others be successful it can only be a positive thing for us
those leaders that help their team succeed and see that it creates opportunities for both the team members
and for them as a leader they embrace change and they see it as a new learning opportunity
you can see how the growth mindset goes hand in hand with an abundance mindset
this again with practice and awareness is just another thing that can be learned perhaps your parents had fixed mindsets
and you were brought up to think that way too by developing your emotional intelligence by practicing some of the
other techniques that we'll talk about later around reframing and strength you can change his mindset and let go of
the fear and it really is a life-changing experience
i remember the first time i learned about locus of control when i was doing my mba and i got so excited because it made
complete sense to me and helped me realize why some people thought and behaved in certain ways and why i behaved
and believed in certain ways and again it goes hand in hand with emotional intelligence
understanding this helped me regulate my own thoughts and feelings better and being a little bit of a control
freak understanding that channeling the internal locus of control gave me all the power and control back pretty
much no matter what the situation i'm facing was was a really empowering realization so for
example my boss yells at me can i control his behavior
no so i reflect on what i can control i can control how i respond to him yelling at me i can control whether i
choose to stay working for him or not i can control whether i choose to talk to him about the behavior right then and
there or at another time when he's calmed down i can control whether i escalate to his
manager or hr regardless of what happens focusing on the internal locus of control gives
me back control over the situation and it makes me feel better about it and allows me to control my emotions
locus of control goes hand in hand with framing framing is about recognizing what story
our brain is telling us and then being able to change it or reframe it it's something that takes
practice once again but it gets easier really quickly the more you do it and it makes a huge impact on your emotions and stress
levels what framing isn't is trying to lie to ourselves our brain is much too clever for that it
never ever works so when the situation occurs our brain automatically pulls together a story
that makes us feel a certain way and experience certain emotions the story is based on our past
experiences and core beliefs often these stories are negative so they immediately impact our emotions and
thoughts in a negative way there's two types of reframing one is context reframing and one is
content reframing content reframing is how changing the wording of something can change the way our brain or the
person receiving the message feels so instead of saying i can't do that for you you say
what i can do for you is it's one of my favorite tools to use at work because people think you're a can do person
just because of the way you frame your content regardless of actually what it is that you're saying context reframing
on the other hand is the example here on the slide so it's whether we either refrain the problem into an opportunity
reframe the weakness into a strength or refrain the hurtful actions of others into understanding why they're doing
that instead of being a victim or engaging in fights a really simple one i catch myself doing
all the time is when i say i have to versus i choose to or i want to
especially on a monday morning it's like you know i have to go to work today stomping around the house getting ready
have to go to work and when i catch myself doing this i can reframe it by saying no i'm choosing to go to work today
because i want to earn money to buy i don't know some new toy or you know i'm choosing to go to work today
because i want to go and see my awesome colleagues that i work with you know once at some point when we're allowed to do that again
so whatever the reason it's about understanding that you do have the choice and you can reframe the way that
you talk to yourself which makes you feel a lot better reframing once again is one of the
things that i found took a lot of repetitive practice but then it becomes second nature and you can catch yourself really quickly
how many of us have read a performance appraisal or any type of feedback and disregarded all the positive things
and go straight to what do we need to improve where's the constructive feedback most perfectionists and achiever
personalities do this because we want to be good at everything one of the things i learned about in my
hr studies many moons ago was gallup's strength based leadership theory it absolutely blew my mind because i'd
spent my whole life focusing on what i needed to improve and my weaknesses and this this meant that i spent a lot
of time especially at work doing things that i didn't enjoy especially process related things
because i was adamant i had to be good at it even though i hated it and i was terrible at it
because so the type of work that people enjoy surprise surprise is based on their strengths which makes complete sense when you read
and understand the theory behind it so gallup strength finder helps you identify your core three to five
strengths and then you focus on making them your superpowers countless studies have shown that we're
more likely to succeed with our superpowers than trying to be an all-rounder and be good or decent at
everything and the huge upside to this is that it's so much more enjoyable and so much more fun
there's a slight caveat sure if you're really really terrible at something you might need to bring it up to a
minimum level if your job role requires it but other than that make sure that your day-to-day work is using your core
strengths and you'll shine and succeed
the self-development of mindset tools we've already talked about help us build resilience and deal with
stress out of a recent survey of 7 500 employees 67 reported experiencing burnout to some
degree and as i mentioned i most certainly have as well as many of my friends and colleagues
burnout is a state of emotional physical and mental exhaustion where you feel overwhelmed and
emotionally drained it reduces productivity and energy and it's caused by excessive and prolonged
stress there's some common work and lifestyle contributors listed on this slide here
but there's also some personality traits that make you really prone to burn out on stress for me i take three out of those four
personality boxes so it's no wonder i've worked hard on it over the years but listening to our bodies for signs of
too much stress can really help us nip it in the bud i mentioned my jaw pain that was definitely an indicator of
stress for me but now that i've fixed that i have a couple of other signs that come up when i'm getting to that overwhelmed and
stressed stage one is that my eye starts twitching and it's super annoying so i can't really
ignore it even if i wanted to but as soon as that happens it means that i need to address it immediately
and start dialing back the stress before burnout were hit another symptom that many people get
including myself are headaches and another one that i've had before is a dry eyes where unless i go to sleep
they just don't get any better so really think about what your stress signs are
and you know write down what those symptoms are so that when you do start to get overwhelmed or stressed you can engage some of the preventative
steps that we're going to talk about to put burn out in reverse
so some of these things we've covered already because they're an ongoing fundamental practice to help us build resilience and understand ourselves
better the two that a lot of research calls out as i mentioned are relationships and sleep
getting enough sleep super important for our mind and body to regenerate and then having a support
network of people that we can talk to that will listen to us is essential counselors and coaches have been an
incredible source of help to me over the years and i'd highly recommend just having an external objective party
to talk to can be really useful we can't and don't have to do everything on our own
another one is taking regular breaks and certainly with working remotely breaks is so so important the scheduling
breaks in between meetings but also still having annual leave it seems really weird booking annual leave
when you can't go anywhere and you're going to be at home but going more than three months without a proper break to reset is dangerous
giving back has also been shown to reduce stress and provide positive feelings to help prevent burnout so it's
another one i'd recommend mentor someone donate something i really like sending little
tokens of appreciation to people when they least expect it so cupcakes or flowers but it makes me
really happy to be able to put a smile on someone else's face all the things on the list are obviously
important but everyone's different so pay attention to what works for you and what helps you de-stress when covert
first hit i got myself a piano to learn piano and it's been an amazing de-stressor even though it's
also challenging but i think because it releases the creative parts of my brain that i don't really get to use a huge amount in my
day-to-day job and the last one i just want to call out is practicing positive self-talk and
being kind to ourselves i think that one can be an ongoing battle especially for
perfectionists and people that are high achievers but the technique that i use is to ask
myself would i say that to someone else or would i talk to someone else that way and often the answer is no
which um which means that you certainly shouldn't be talking to yourself in that way or saying those things to
yourself this one was really interesting so a health psychologist named kelly
mcgonagall did a tedx talk on how to make stress your friend and the talk explains how the neural
hormone oxytocin which is also called the stress hormone works on our brains and our bodies it
enhances our empathy and motivates us to seek support and it relaxes our blood vessels during stress and helps our hearts regenerate
it also releases when we're supporting someone else with stress and the more that's released the healthier your stress
responses and the faster you recover from stress i'll let you watch the talk for yourself
but the spoiler is that the studies they conducted showed that the belief of stress being bad for you
indicated an increase in death of 43 over the rest of the subjects who were
still stressed but they didn't share that belief that stress was bad for you another study they did focusing on
people with increased stress events such as financial strain or family crisis that increased their risk of
dying by 30 percent showed that if they'd been caring for or helping others during this time
they actually had a zero increased risk in dying rather than the 30 percent so i think it's worth to at least try
and think about stress in a different way and to remember that caring for and helping others has
not just mental health benefits that we talked about earlier but also could prolong our life which is pretty
cool so we spent a fair bit of time thinking about our minds and our bodies and understanding ourselves
the final piece in this puzzle is understanding what success looks like for us and i'm talking about success across
life not just work because we have one life so to me it's work-life integration rather than work-life balance
so being crystal clear on what good looks like is what will enable you to achieve it and tune out other people's noise and expectations
of course everyone is different so for some a successful life might be going on two family holidays a year or it might
be retiring in a certain age or a specific career achievement maybe it's being recognized with an award
or maybe it's just finding a life partner or having kids there's a million different life designs
out there but figuring out what the picture of success looks like for you and you alone means that you can achieve
it and it may not be something fancy maybe it's just to live a good life there's a really
great book that i read called how much is enough and i found that really eye-opening because it highlights the changes over
the past 100 or so years and the role that marketing has played in what many of our picture of success now looks like
a really nice way to start this process as well is to create a vision board and it doesn't have to be old school
with magazine cutouts and pictures for those of you that don't like art and craft because i'm not really an
autocraft fan you can do an electronic version using powerpoint or photoshop and digital
images but it's a really nice way if you're not quite sure what what good looks like for you to
start playing around with that picture
working smarter not harder is one of my favorite things to share and discuss because learning these techniques has
saved me from burnout and definitely reduced my stress massively the first piece is understanding the
difference between being productive and being efficient you can be super efficient and get so
much done in a day or a week i've always prided myself on being very efficient being able to smash through
double the workload of someone else because of course the more efficient you are the more things you can fit into
your day your week your month but this won't stop you from being stressed or burning out it could
actually make it worse it will let you achieve maybe two or three times as much as your colleague
but it's not sustainable and if you're a leader you may not have the choice anymore because you may not be hands on
delivering so you have to start working in another way productivity on the other hand is what
we're going to delve deeply into over the next few slides and can really change your life
i want you to ask yourself if you're good at multitasking i'm a woman so in theory i must be
fabulous at multitasking right no no no no multitasking is not actually
a thing we can only focus our attention on one thing at a time and when we split our attention we can't
process all the information how many times have you been having a conversation with someone and you
overhear another really interesting conversation just behind you so you try and keep one
ear on that conversation as well but then all of a sudden you've missed like the entire sentence that the person just said and
they asked and they asked you a question and you're screwed so that's a multitasking fail so we just need to all stop even trying
to do it the first step to being productive is focusing on one thing at a time
one of my favorite sayings is if you fail to plan you plan to fail in order to be productive you need to
understand what you what it is you're trying to achieve you need to set goals that are tied to achieving the overall strategy or vision
and then break them down into long medium and short term goals long term is your five to ten year goals
and these can be rough and most definitely can change medium term is your one to three years and then
short is your three to nine months interestingly studies show that we generally over estimate what we can do
in one year but underestimate what we can do in five and as we talked about earlier
ideally goals should be life not just work it should be a combination
and some of your goals especially in that medium one to three year range might just be to keep doing what you're doing
which is fine but deciding that makes it purposeful so personally for me i have long term
goals that you know send me a retirement less work more travel one day
and then i have a lot of short term ones across work and life but my one to three year goals are to
keep doing what i'm doing because i'm happy with the balance that my life has and i'm keen for it to stay that way for the next couple of years
but you revisit your goals regularly so every three to six months you want to do a check-in on how things are progressing and update anything
that's changed so being productive is really developing
these four areas prioritizing and understanding the urgent versus important matrix
is one of the best things that you can learn we get so caught up in the never-ending
inbox or the random questions from people and most of it's not important and i'm not urgent
so i love this matrix because it makes it really clear and it just makes so much sense
once again this is a learnt practice so you know while you're getting used to it you just refer back to the matrix and
you go okay where does this fit um if it's not important and not urgent then either you should be delegating it
or considering whether you do it at all procrastination is something i've always
been pretty pretty fabulous at um which is not a good thing i remember watching a tedx talk
about why we procrastinate while i was procrastinating my uni assignment um so yeah very good we want to be an
expert in not procrastinating i know some people who set their own imaginary deadlines so that
can work for some people for me that's never really worked um for me it's having clear goals and timelines that
are set at a relatively detailed level and that will help me avoid procrastination i've also found that using reward
techniques can help me so if i have a if i have a list of things that i want to do today i will say i'll say to myself okay
if i can get these done by 2 p.m you know i'm going to have a nap or i'm going to have a cup of tea and a
chocolate and watch it watch a tv show um so whatever works for you but we all have
something that motivates us another really cool book i read over christmas actually is called atomic
habits and it gives a whole heap of techniques in this area
one section that i really enjoyed specifically was changing and creating habits was about
how your identity plays a part so rather than saying i'm going to stop procrastinating or
even saying i'm going to tick the things off my list every day and stop procrastinating
you say i'm someone who completes the things on my list by 2 pm every day
and it's a really subtle shift but it's been proven to make a huge difference when you identify with
identify as somebody who does it not somebody who's going to do it or who wants to do it
i've tried it since the beginning of january on exercising every day which i've never in my life done or
wanted to do um and it's been really really successful and even better and actually enjoying it
which is really weird the other section is big rocks so this
refers to this big strategic things that you want to work on or put time in to investigate more
and these are generally in the not urgent but important box and they're the ones that always get pushed back and push back if you haven't
created space for them and prioritize them so these things that they can make a huge long-term
difference and you really have to make space and understand what they are so make sure that you've got those those
clear big rocks identified and then make sure that you make time for them and we'll talk about another couple of tips for that later
so having goals and clear priorities allows you to push back pushing back is a really important skill
to develop and really essential to being productive when your manager asks you to do
something you can generally fit it into one of three categories yes because you have capacity yes
but which of these other priorities would you like me to drop in order to do this or yes i can do that within the next x
number of days or x number of weeks you always want a manager to know that you're happy to help but
you need to provide them visibility into your goals and priorities so that they understand if you need to push back and so that they feel like
they have some control over it giving them that insight also prevents micromanagement
i've had a few micromanagers in my time but the worst one i had a few a decent amount of years back now
thankfully made me desperately want to quit my job and i was miserable however it turned
out the job market at the time was really crap so i couldn't find anything and i ended up staying for
another few years and i'm so glad i did because that manager taught me so much about dealing with micromanagers
i was able to put some structure in place and give the manager the visibility that he wanted and initially i reported back to him
with weekly progress updates within about three months he completely left me alone and moved on to micromanaging someone else
sorry but i'd been able to give him the confidence that i had a clear plan and give him that feeling of control by
sharing the progress updates with him and giving him the option of changing priorities knowing that others would
have to drop or timelines would have to change if you chose to do that which you stopped doing quite quickly
so pushing back becomes a lot easier if you have those clear goals and
priorities assessing all of the time consuming and manual things you do with the view of
simplifying them and making them repeatable also increases productivity massively
one of the things that i like to use are email signature templates so they're a really great way to address
similar questions that keep coming up from internal or external people so you can just create the answer create
the template save it in your email template list and just use it when those repeatable things come up
for internal teams you can also create wikis single sources of truth so you can point people to self-service
options rather than them relying on you every time inbox can be one of the
biggest causes of stress and the most unproductive uses of our time so ideally
you want to action emails immediately by responding deleting or moving them into a folder
if they build up and you end up with a giant inbox rather than let it stress you out face facts that if you haven't gone back
to something in a few weeks you probably won't and if it's important somebody's probably going to follow up with you
so delete them if you're really busy or move them into a when i get time
folder and i guarantee you won't go back and look in that folder which probably just means they weren't urgent
or important because once again you can't care about everything so it's okay to admit that sometimes you
just don't care enough to do something because it's not a priority for you we put so much stress and pressure on
ourselves to care about everything but we just can't we have to we can't make everything a priority
when i used to see people in my from my team in the office after six pm i would ask them is anyone going to die
if you don't do this until tomorrow and surprise surprise the answer unless it was a doctor or a
nurse was no no one's going to die if you wait until tomorrow to do something or get back to someone
so we really need to stop putting so much unnecessary pressure on ourselves and set realistic expectations when we
can from the get go so under promise over deliver where possible
now once you're clear on your goals and your priorities you can schedule your time to be most productive
using your calendar to use blocks to allocate time to strategic work projects admin emails and
scheduling gaps in your calendar for urgent and important things that are generally going to come up most days
not back to back in your meetings which i mentioned earlier one of the techniques that i implemented last year
was reducing all of my one-hour meetings to 45 and all of my 30 minute meetings to 20
minutes and it's amazing you can fit exactly the same amount in just a little bit more efficient but it
creates these gaps and these headspaces for you in between your day and it really
reduces stress but also i would say beware of meetings in general try not to accept meetings
if you don't need to be in them and push back if there's no value for you being there also push for meetings to have some sort
of agenda or purpose and request that people prep before attending meetings because this makes
for productive and efficient meetings another really awesome book that i love
is called freda focus by michael hyatt and i had some really great tips on productivity one of the ones that i took
on board was being purposeful about scheduling my week into internal external and strategic days and
depending on your role maybe internal and external don't apply but being really purposeful
and i was telling one of my colleagues about it and she looked at me really concerned and she said how do your customers feel about that
like surely you need to be flexible for them and what i said to her is that most of
the time if you give your customer a few options of when you're available they're happy to pick one if you're
purposeful about making your external meeting days on a tuesday and a thursday every week then you know what 95 of the time the
customers are going to have enough flexibility to choose an option structuring my week like this made me so
much more productive because i was able to focus and get into the flow state and get through stuff
much faster on those internal days and i always had time for those big rocks on my strategic days so i was really able
to make big changes and big impact in my career another technique i implemented from the
book was having a daily to-do list and each day and a weekly so each day and week
really being clear on if i just do three things today or three big things this week what what
is going to equal success what are those three things so really trying to narrow it down to just three key priorities each day and
each week and these these things have come from the short-term goals and the medium-term
goals that you've set yourself and doing this is how you can continue to deliver results and also have a clear
sense of achievement without it being overwhelming for you because i don't know about you but when i wake up in the morning and i have a
list like this straight away i'm like can you see my hands yep straight away i'm like oh
i don't even know where to start the list is too big so honestly that three rule changed changed my life definitely
so it's a really big shift when you move into a team lead or manager role and have to start delivering through
other people and not on your own anymore i know for i know i found it really really difficult when i first moved into that
type of role because it's more about motivating others and it's a very different type of noise and often it's a lot more noisy
all of the questions all of the time it feels like everyone wants a piece of you and at the end of the day or the end of
the week you look around and you're like what did i even achieve this week it can feel really reactive
and it can be really hard to feel successful so my biggest lesson learned over the
years is dealing with people asking you questions don't answer the
question which may sound harsh but 95 of the time the person either already knows the
answer or they can figure out the answer if you help them just by asking them some probing questions if you give people the
answers they will just keep coming back to you every time with questions and you'll never get rid of the noise
people also appreciate you taking the time to help them actually figure out the answer for themselves
they feel empowered and successful because they solve the problem without you just telling them the answer
so this can be really really challenging at first and it does take a bit more time in the beginning
but it's such it just dials down so much noise if you can repeatedly do it and it's definitely a
skill that you can just learn and develop by practice
empowering your team and not delegating to them is what really gives you a lot of time back as a leader
in my last role i had 80 developers reporting directly to me it was pretty full on um and without
knowing how to empower people i would have burnt out in about a week so bringing together your senior people
from the team and sharing the strategy and the visions for them with them is the first step then work
collaboratively to come up with the short-term and the medium-term goals because the long-term goals have probably been set by the cxo
once these goals are agreed give complete ownership and empowerment of individual goals to specific team
members and enable them to go and involve the wider teams to deliver them however they want
let people choose which goals they want to own so a process of opt-in for everyone leads to better outcomes
and if people understand and buy into the vision and the goals they do want to opt in people want to add value they want to leave things they
want to make a difference what you do need to still do as a leader is set the expectations of any progress
updates timelines reporting that you need for each goal and most importantly you want
people to know that you're there to support them to remove blockers or whatever else they might need
dan pink's book drive is another one of my favorites on why autonomy mastery and purpose is so important for people
and definitely worth a read if you haven't yet
so we talked about identifying our own superpowers it's exactly the same for your team if they're doing what they're good at
they'll be more productive and engaged as a leader you want to form your teams where possible
based on their strengths consider what different hats are needed for the goal for the project and then bring people in
that have those strengths maybe it's someone who's great at stakeholder management maybe it's technical mentorship or
technical leadership maybe it's front-end or back-end development because we all know that's not the same person
maybe it's the team cheerleader you know that person who um they're really positive and they
naturally make everybody feel good and they get the team together for lunches or coffee you know every team is going to require
a different bunch of hats and skills but be purposeful about selecting where you can people that have those strength
areas when recruiting into your team as well it's looking at the same thing
what are the strength gaps within your team and then higher for those strengths diversity in your
team will make it more successful and a lot more fun and i have a whole nother talk about
recruitment tips because that can be a big can of worms in my experience and quite challenging
as a leader your life is a lot easier if you have an engaged team so empowering them giving them autonomy
giving them insight into the strategy and vision plays a really big part in engagement but purpose and mastery
will be engaged by creating a team culture that's built on shared values so if your organization already has
values just make sure that they're broken down and meaningful for your team if they
don't have shared values already then create them collaboratively with your team
you can make them core values or principles at amazon we have leadership principles
and we also have team tenants which really helps define what good looks like for our team and what behaviors we
expect providing flexibility and choice are two of the other key things that you need to
provide to your team to keep them engaged as we talked about earlier the worst thing you can do is be a micromanager
i've interviewed literally thousands of people who were leaving their jobs purely for that reason and the other
important piece of a strong team culture is celebrating success celebrating the small wins ideally tying
some sort of recognition program to the values because it will help drive the culture and behaviours that you want to
see within the team my side hustle because everyone has a side hustle nowadays is the ceo of a
company called shout out and this was we created we created this to address this exact challenge
so enabling peer-to-peer recognition which is really important but then tying that into management
recognition through an awards program which is also really important recognition and rewards don't need to be
expensive it's generally not about the money if you're looking for ideas on how to do this i've got plenty of free tips
and also paid suggestions um so feel free to reach out afterwards and i'm happy to share i also
have a blog on my shoutout.cloud website with lots of different ideas as well

empathy is called out in study after study as one of the most effective leadership traits and great news
empathy is just another skill that absolutely can be learned and developed through practice
when i did my first site profile close to 20 years ago now the business coach that i was working with at the time
said wow i'm not sure i've ever seen anyone get zero on this and at the time i was
wondering why my staff turnover was so high it took me probably five years of
practice to get it to a decent level um but i've continued to build on it over the last
20 years and now empathy is one of my highest results on those tests and not just because i know how to work the test
but it's actually one of my core strengths and something that's really helped in my leadership success over the years
empathy is not sympathy it's just taking the time to listen and understand people and see and feel things from their

wants and that every employee employee wants their leader to have
i'm assuming there's probably a lot of people on here today from the uk so you may not be aware that the icon that i

need regular and transparent communication from their leader it will make it easier if you have a
communication plan and i know when i say those words i half shudder and half roll my eyes
but i'm just talking about a really simple structure of why when and how maybe it's a weekly
customer or a project update email a four nightly sales pipeline email a monthly newsletter a quarterly
roundtable or an all hands you don't have to be responsible as the leader for delivering all of these
things you should definitely be empowering others to own them and automate as much as you can but as a leader you do need to make sure
that it's happening and create or sign off on the communication plan
it's really important part of our job as leaders that we're reminding everyone in these worrisome times that
everything's going to be okay it's amazing how calming these words can be for people so we want to try and ease
anxiety for our team the fear of the unknown is one of the biggest causes of anxiety
people can deal with good news they can deal with bad news but the unknown is really really stressful and this is what we're addressing by
having some sort of communication plan and regular communication and updates
it's also our job as a leader to provide regular feedback to individuals in our team we touched on it earlier that many of us
focus just on the constructive feedback and interestingly the ratio of positive to negative feedback
is seven to one in order for people to actually take the positive feedback on board
so that means a lot of great jobs and thank you and while these are important research
also shows that people want specificity to make it more meaningful so when you're calling out someone's
great work try to tell them why it was great and how they specifically added value
on the flip side constructive feedback needs to be immediate objective and really clear nip it in the
bud is one of my favorite terms i don't know if it's an australian one and you haven't heard of it but um nip
it in the bud i love it and if you let things drag on it gets so much worse and so much more daunting to
deal with so as a leader found firsthand that people really appreciate honest and
direct feedback it still surprises me sometimes the depth of relationship and respect that
you gain when you do this for people i actually had an ex-team member tagged me in a linkedin post a few months ago
that was talking about great leaders that you've worked with and it was someone that i had to give quite harsh feedback to
after some previous leaders had basically written them off as too hard to deal with and i wasn't really sure how they felt
about me so when i saw that tag i was like oh so what i found is that
people would rather know the feedback even if it's just a perception rather than be ignored or not dealt with
and i've had many examples like this over the years and some of the people that i'm closest with now are people that have had to give quite robust
feedback to and yes it is uncomfortable doing this at first but with practice and the right
intentions of wanting to actually help your team members it does become a lot easier and it actually becomes really rewarding
we all work hard and are so busy so part of us having a sustainable and enjoyable life is experiencing success and even better
contentment we've talked about what good looks like and setting goals and celebrating wins
but i wanted to run through a few other tips that in my experience helps us to stay in this zone and really enjoy our

unfortunately this is human nature in our current society we talked earlier about defining what

behavior because we don't care what anyone else is doing we have our own clear focus of what we

i think hiring a boat is a way better idea than buying one and if i decide then that hiring a boat

hiring a boat three to four times a year on my what good looks like picture um and you know what
that's only gonna set me back about three thousand dollars a year instead of hundreds of thousands so it's a double win but we all have
control over whether we focus on ourselves and enjoy our life or whether we're always looking at other people and comparing ourselves
to them does anyone else roll their eyes when
they hear people talking about mindfulness and living in the now full transparency i do i'm one of those
people when i look at this picture i think it's so beautiful but if i was sitting there i would last
about five minutes before i'd be bought out of my brains so the meditation type of mindfulness
isn't for everyone but yes it works for some and if you're one of those people then good on you and
keep up the good work it's very good for you for me what i've learned over the years is that mindfulness is about
appreciation and moments it's easy to soak up every moment of our time with busyness
distractions technology tv love netflix for me mindfulness is literally just
about stopping to take a breath a few times a day taking a moment to appreciate my surroundings whether it's
looking at around the office to see my awesome colleagues or walking outside and looking up at the gorgeous clouds
just for a moment taking that moment to acknowledge how lucky i am to be here right now
right then and there so just take a few moments each day to remember who you are where you are
and why you are and it's amazing how doing something so simple and so fast can help you clear your mind and
help you focus on the rest of your day once again and so if longer more formal
meditation is not for you then give this technique a try instead and it works really well
so talking again about mark manson and one of my favorite books he talks about how our brains work and how they need to
solve problems and how if you solve all the problems in your life your brain will actually create more problems for you to solve
i don't know whether any of you have experienced this before but i've definitely blown up my life a couple of times when things were going too well
and things were too calm and that is not what you want so thankfully now i've learnt this lesson
and i understand the why behind how my brain works so i make sure that my life has plenty of the problems that i love to solve in
it and i'm not striving to get rid of them anymore because i know i need them in my life so make sure you take a few moments to
think about what kind of problems you enjoy solving and consider whether you have these in your work and in your life
